Award.AwardTitle: Social Identity in Online Microfinance and Public Goods Provision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project represents an interdisciplinary research effort to investigate the effects of social identity on lender behavior in an online microfinance community (kiva.org) and the selection of social identities. Social identity research in economics predicts that a salient group identity and group competition increases individual contribution to public goods.

The researchers will apply social identity and social preference theory to analyze the Kiva lending data at the individual and team level. Results from the analysis will yield insights to one of the most important yet unresolved problems in social identity research, the selection of identity and the formation of norms within a social group. This work represents the first attempt to bridge text and network data mining techniques with social identity theory. Novel text mining and machine learning models will be developed that advance the state-of-the-art of mining of online communities.

More than one billion people globally live in absolute poverty, most also excluded from the formal banking sector. To alleviate poverty, microfinance programs emerge in many parts of the world to provide small loans to the poor. Currently about 10 million households are served by microfinance programs. This research investigates incentives to increase lender participation and lending activities on Kiva. Preliminary analysis indicates that the lending teams program is effective in increasing loan activities. Results from the analysis will benefit Kiva and other microfinance programs. Increased participation and lending activities will help realize the World Bank's goal of serving 100 million poor households.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we use experimental, computational and theoretical methods to study the effects of social identity and team competition on lender behavior in an online microfinance community (kiva.org).

Through the lens of social identity and social preference theory, we analyze the Kiva lending data at the individual and team level. We bridge the social science and computational approaches by building social identity theory into our computational models, which, in turn, more accurately classify a much larger set of motivations than any previously available to social scientists. Results from our empirical analysis yields insights to several unresolved theoretical problems in the mathematical models of social identity, i.e., mechanisms for successful team competition, the endogenous selection of identity and the endogenous formation of behavioral norms within a social group. Building on the insights from our empirical analysis, we then conduct several experiments to test various hypotheses in a more controlled setting.

A large body of experimental research in economics and social psychology, mostly conducted in the laboratory, has demonstrated that the existence of teams can increase public goods provision and improve coordination. However, it is an open question whether team competition increases lending activity in a natural field setting, and if so, by how much and why. In our work, we investigate the effect of team membership on pro-social lending. We do so through both an empirical analysis of naturally-occurring field data and randomized field experiments which explore the effectiveness of goal setting and coordination within a lending team. Our research contributes to Economics by demonstrating the existence and quantifying the effects of team competition in the field.

In our second field experiment which recommends teams to Kiva lenders, we are able to cleanly identify the effects of team membership on pro-social lending. The team built recommender systems which recommend Kiva teams to lenders who did not belong to any team, based on their location, or past loan history, or the leaderboard. We conducted a randomized field experiment on the Kiva platform in May 2014 and followed our lenders for the subsequent two months. We find that team recommendation based on location similarity has significantly higher rate of team joining than the control condition or any other treatments. Conditional on joining a team, new team members lend significantly more compared to those in the control condition, regardless of which treatment they belong to.

Our study also integrate social identity theory into machine learning. In a new working paper, we proposed a novel statistical topic model that is motivated by insights of social identity theory. Our basic intuition was the analogy between group identities (of users) in online communities and topic identities (of word tokens) in text documents. In particular, a word token is allowed to have multiple topic identities, and can randomly switch between the identities under different circumstances. In our model, one topic identity can be reinforced by certain properties of the identity, for example the number of tokens that have been assigned to this topic (analogical to the size of a community, or the salience of an identity). By doing this, the new topic model can be initialized with many topics and eventually evolve into a moderate number of topics through the natural competition process among the topic identities. Topics that ``survive'' from this process provides a good summary of the data collection, which outperformed the classical topic models.
